feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued August 24 at 7:21AM AKDT until August 24 at 10:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM AKDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense fog. * WHERE...Eastern Baranof Island and Southern Admiralty Island, including Angoon. And from Kupreanof Island to Northern Prince of Wales, including Kake and Edna Bay. * WHEN...Until 10 AM AKDT this morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Baranof Island and Southern Admiralty Island; Inner Channels from Kupreanof Island to Etolin Island

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued August 24 at 7:21AM AKDT until August 24 at 10:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...DENSE FOG ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM AKDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense fog. * WHERE...Western Prince of Wales including, Craig, Klawock, and Hydaburg. * WHEN...Until 10 AM AKDT this morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dixon Entrance to Cape Decision Coastal Area

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 24 at 4:18AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...STRONG WINDS AND HIGH SURF EXPECTED FROM KIPNUK TO THE MOUTH OF THE KUSKOKWIM RIVER THURSDAY... A cold front will track across the eastern Bering Wednesday night into Thursday. Southerly wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph are expected along the Kuskokwim Delta coast and across Kuskokwim Bay. High surf of 1 to 3 feet above the normal highest tide line is possible

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 24 at 4:10AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...RISING WATER LEVELS ON SMALL STREAMS AND CREEKS DRAINING THE BROOKS RANGE... A series of fronts will impact the region, bringing copious amounts of widespread rain that will cause water levels to rise on small streams and creeks draining the south slopes of the Western Brooks Range.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Kobuk and Noatak Valleys; Upper Kobuk and Noatak Valleys

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 24 at 4:10AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...ELEVATED SURF THURSDAY AND FRIDAY... Strong south winds to 25 to 35 mph will move into the West Coast and bring elevated surf to parts of Norton Sound and the Yukon Delta on Thursday, persisting into Friday before they diminish. Wave action will combine with storm surge and be the greatest along south facing coastlines, with anticipated storm surge
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Yukon Delta

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 23 at 9:41PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...MULTIPLE HEAVY RAIN EVENTS TO ARRIVE FRIDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY... Multiple weather fronts are expected to move into the Southeast Alaska forecast area from Friday to Wednesday. The Northeast Gulf will already be saturated with rains from midweek, and lighter rains spreading into the panhandle Thursday will begin to prime the remainder of the panhandle region.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cape Decision to Salisbury Sound Coastal Area; Cape Fairweather to Cape Suckling Coastal Area; Dixon Entrance to Cape Decision Coastal Area; Eastern Baranof Island and Southern Admiralty Island; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Haines Borough and Lynn Canal; Inner Channels from Kupreanof Island to Etolin Island; Juneau Borough and Northern Admiralty Island; Misty Fjords; Salisbury Sound to Cape Fairweather Coastal Area; Southern Inner Channels; Taiya Inlet and Klondike Highway

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 23 at 2:37PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Glacier Dammed lake release causing debris to flow into Controller Bay... Satellite observations indicate that the Berg glacier dammed lake, located 65 miles east of Cordova, has likely released downstream into the Gandil River, Bering River and Bering Lake. High water from this glacier dammed lake release usually lasts for several days with large areas

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 23 at 12:55PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM AKDT SATURDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by elevated river levels will continue into the weekend. * WHERE...The mainstem Kenai River is the most likely place to experience minor flooding. * WHEN...Until 500 PM AKDT Saturday.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 24 at 10:54AM CDT until August 24 at 1:15PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 115 PM CDT THIS AFTERNOON FOR NORTHWESTERN MARENGO AND SOUTHERN SUMTER COUNTIES... At 1054 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 3 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.5 to 1 inch in 1 hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 24 at 9:06AM CDT until August 24 at 11:45AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1145 AM CDT THIS MORNING FOR NORTHEASTERN RANKIN COUNTY... At 906 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 4 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 24 at 5:17AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAT INDEX VALUES BETWEEN 105 AND 109 DEGREES ARE EXPECTED TODAY... The combination of warm temperatures and high dewpoints will produce heat indices between 105 and 109 degrees today. Residents with outdoor activities planned are urged to drink plenty of water, wear light weight and light colored clothing and take frequent breaks from the heat. Young children and pets should never be left
